item.title: The Wolf Of All Streets â€“ BTC Worst Q4 in 7 Years. Bottom or Breakdown? #CryptoTownHall
item.description:
This end-of-year episode of Crypto Town Hall brings together a panel of crypto experts to dissect Bitcoin's underwhelming Q4 performanceâ€”the worst in seven yearsâ€”while reflecting on 2025, navigating tricky price action, and considering the evolving role of Bitcoin and its market structure. The discussion aims to demystify what's driving capitulation, why Bitcoin lags behind assets like gold and silver, and how new financial products, like advanced options, are shaping liquidity and volatility. The panel covers institutional behavior, changing investor demographics, altcoins, DeFi, AI's role, and future adoption themes, all with the goal to frame what's next for crypto in 2026.

]]>

item.title: What Bitcoin Did â€“ 2026 Macro Outlook and What It Means for Bitcoin | Joe Carlasare
item.description:
Joe Carlasare joins the show for a breakdown of why Bitcoinâ€™s sideways year has been so widely misread, and why sentiment today is the worst it's been. We get into why 2025 fell below expectations, why Bitcoinâ€™s lack of volatility pushed capital toward AI stocks and gold, and the fall out from the October 10th liquidation event.

We get into why the four year cycle narrative no longer fits a market shaped by ETFs, options, and institutional hedging, why calendar based thinking has become a liability, and why a year of consolidation may be working off excess rather than signalling weakness. Joe explains why a new all time high in 2026 would be one of the most bullish developments in Bitcoinâ€™s history, permanently breaking cycle psychology, and lays out what could shift Bitcoin from hard mode back into a structurally bullish macro asset as liquidity, positioning, and confidence come back.

item.title: Bitcoin Today Recast â€“ Bitcoin Today Recast 12/29/25
item.description:
Bitcoin Today Recast brings you the latest from todayâ€™s live X Space.

Today hosted by Darkside at 8:30 AM PST.

We dove deep into the wild silver price action thatâ€™s gripped the marketsâ€”silver rocketed to new all-time highs above $80 per ounce amid massive demand, supply squeezes, and speculative fervor, only to see a sharp pullback today with dramatic drops into the low-to-mid $70s range. We broke down the role of paper metals trading on exchanges like COMEX, where massive volumes dwarf annual physical production, fueling discussions on manipulation, margin hikes triggering flash crashes, and the growing divide between paper claims and actual physical supply.

We also explored parallels to possible paper dynamics in Bitcoin, questioning how derivatives and institutional products might influence price discovery in similar ways.

The conversation then shifted to the Bitcoin community itselfâ€”addressing the increasing fragmentation, heated character assassinations, name-calling, and unproductive drama unfolding in spaces and online. We emphasized the need to step back, recognize weâ€™re all on the same team fighting for sound money and individual sovereignty, and work toward mending these fences for a stronger, more united ecosystem.

Sharp insights, real talk, and community-focused reflectionsâ€”perfect for Bitcoiners who value principles over division. Tune in, subscribe, and catch the full episode now on Spotify, Apple, or your favorite podcast app!

Follow @lorenhodl on X for live updates and join the conversation tomorrow at 8:30 AM PST.

item.title: Rob Wallace | Bitcoin News â€“ The Genetic Mutation That Makes Bitcoin Perfect Money | Jesse Myers
item.description:
Bitcoin isn't just a new technology, but the logical conclusion of "Monetary Darwinism". From the genetic mutations that gave Homo sapiens a cognitive edge in perceiving scarcity to the reason why elite business graduates often dismiss Bitcoin, Jesse Myers joins Rob Wallace for a conversation covers the past, present, and future of our speciesâ€™ relationship with money.

Jesse Myers, head of Bitcoin strategy at SmarterWeb, Stanford MBA, and the mind behind the "Once in a Species" blog, dives deep into the intersection of neuroscience, human evolution, and the burgeoning "Bitcoin Treasury Company" model that is transforming global finance.

Topics covered in this episode include:

â€¢ Why Bitcoin is wired into human evolution and our obsession with scarcity

â€¢ How a specific genetic mutation may explain money, civilization, and Bitcoin adoption

â€¢ Why elite finance and MBA culture dismiss Bitcoin and what eventually breaks that mindset

â€¢ Bitcoin as monetary Darwinism and the perfection of scarce money

â€¢ Why Bitcoin is still only ~0.2% of global asset value

â€¢ How Bitcoin treasury companies compound Bitcoin per share

â€¢ The rise of preferred equity, fixed income products, and â€œdigital creditâ€ built on Bitcoin

â€¢ Michael Saylorâ€™s strategy and why TradFi is starting to engage with Bitcoin

â€¢ Why treasury companies could eventually hold up to 50% of all Bitcoin

â€¢ The risks, volatility, and consolidation coming to the Bitcoin treasury sector

â€¢ How capital markets, not governments, drive Bitcoin monetization

â€¢ Why Bitcoin is the Trojan horse that brings TradFi onto a Bitcoin standard

]]>

item.title: Bitcoin Policy Institute â€“ Congressman Warren Davidson Unveils the â€œBitcoin for America Actâ€ | Spotlight Series #1
item.description:
In this exclusive interview, Congressman Warren Davidson announces the introduction of the Bitcoin for America Act, legislation that could redefine how the United States adopts Bitcoin and how Americans fulfill their tax obligations.Hosted by Conner Brown, Head of Strategy at the Bitcoin Policy Institute (BPI), this premiere episode of the BPI Spotlight Series explores:â€¢ Codifying the Strategic Bitcoin Reserveâ€¢ Allowing Americans to pay federal taxes in Bitcoinâ€¢ Eliminating capital gains taxes when Bitcoin is used for tax paymentsâ€¢ Strengthening national security and economic resilience through sound moneyâ€¢ Preserving financial privacy in a digital eraâ€¢ Encouraging grassroots adoption and opt-in contributions to a national Bitcoin reserveâ€¢ Reestablishing the United States as the global leader in Bitcoin innovationWhy it matters:The United States faces unprecedented debt pressures and growing competition over the future of money. Davidson argues that Bitcoin provides a durable path toward financial stability, technological leadership, and renewed economic freedom for the American people.Key topics covered:â€¢ Bitcoin tax reform and de minimis payment exemptionsâ€¢ National competitiveness in the digital asset economyâ€¢ Inflation, fiscal policy, and sovereign savings strategyâ€¢ CBDC risks and the importance of privacy-preserving moneyâ€¢ Gen Z financial opportunity and long-term savingsFor viewers interested in Bitcoin policy, economic strategy, and Americaâ€™s financial future, this discussion offers essential insight into how forward-looking legislation could shape the decades ahead.Contact your elected representatives and encourage support for the Bitcoin for America Act.Subscribe for more policy-focused interviews and expert research from the Bitcoin Policy Institute.

]]>

item.title: Stephan Livera Podcast â€“ Has Lightning Quietly Succeeded? with Nate (Beeforbacon) | SLP708
item.description:
In this conversation, I discuss with Nate the current state and future prospects of the Lightning Network as of December 2025. They explore various aspects such as payment success rates, public perception versus practitioner insights, routing fees, centrality in nodes, yield opportunities, privacy considerations, and the overall adoption of the Lightning Network. The discussion highlights the improvements made over the years, the economic incentives for node operators, and the importance of community-driven initiatives in shaping the future of the Lightning Network.

=Takeaways:

ğŸ”¸The Lightning Network has improved payment success rates over time.

ğŸ”¸Public perception of the Lightning Network often differs from actual usage statistics.

ğŸ”¸Routing fees are crucial for maintaining liquidity and economic incentives in the network.

ğŸ”¸Centrality in Lightning nodes affects payment success and routing efficiency.

ğŸ”¸Yield opportunities exist for those operating Lightning nodes.

ğŸ”¸Adoption of the Lightning Network is expected to grow as more enterprises recognize its benefits.

ğŸ”¸Privacy in Lightning transactions is nuanced and requires careful management.

ğŸ”¸Innovations in Lightning technology continue to enhance user experience and functionality.

ğŸ”¸The future of the Lightning Network may involve more integration with traditional financial systems.

ğŸ”¸Community-driven initiatives are essential for the growth and improvement of the Lightning Network.

item.title: The Bitcoin Boomers â€“ QE on Steroids, Bitcoin Business Revolution, Public Miner Doom | Gary Cardone
item.description:
Gary Cardone (energy veteran, fintech pioneer, and acclaimed artist) joins Larry Lepard, Bob Burnett, and Gary Leland for a no-holds-barred Bitcoin Boomers episode that exposes the fiat system's soul-crushing traps and Bitcoin's path to ultimate freedom. From the opening salvo, Gary drops bombs: "Bitcoin is the primary business without an HR department," freeing him from "dumb meetings about dumb subjects" to pursue art and self-discovery.

The crew dismantles fiat's "treadmill" (Larry: "The only thing more limited than Bitcoin is your timeâ€”and Bitcoin gives it back"), warns of ethical "prostitution" in corporate ladders, and reveals how creatives spot Bitcoin's magic first by thinking outside the box. Bob slams public miners' impending doom amid 2025's $8.6B M&A frenzy and harsh margins, while championing decentralized energy "sinkholes" for wasted power.

Larry's prescient "big print" prophecy hits home as the Fed ended QT in December 2025, restarting QE with $40B/month Treasury buys amid liquidity strainsâ€”fueling Bitcoin's hedge role despite its dip to ~$87K from $126K highs. They debate deflationary shocks from immigration policies, why success isn't chasing dollars (Gary: "Even billionaires don't get freedom"), and raw advice for young stackers: ditch consumerism, seek mentors, pay yourself first with 10% in BTC for compounding magic.This is the orange-pill blueprint for boomers and millennials alikeâ€”escape fiat's rat race before the next debasement wave.

If you're tired of quarterly BS and ready for Bitcoin's no-HR revolution, hit play now. item.title: Bitcoin Audible â€“ Chat_155 - Where We Are, Where We've Been, & Where We're Going with Ben Kaufman
item.description:
â€œYou donâ€™t want money that is not a good store of value. Weâ€™re in a very specific point in human history where that exists, but thatâ€™s not the default, right? We have to remember that. These more or less last hundred years - this is just a very small spot in human history where we all happened to be born - where money is not a good store of value, right? Because governments have coerced it upon us. But it wasnâ€™t like that before.

Itâ€™s not the normal state of things. The normal state of things is that money is a good store of value, right? Gold was a good store of value. In other societies, it was a good store of value in various materials, right? We donâ€™t need to get into the history of money. But the important thing to remember is that we are the exception. We are the anomaly where something went kind of wrong and has to be fixed.â€
~ Ben Kaufman

I sit down with Ben Kaufman to catch up and take stock of where Bitcoin actually is right now. We dig into the four-year cycle, whether it still matters, and what ETFs, politics, and financialization have changed about the culture.

Ben shares insights from his work on Miniscript and Bitcoin Keeper, including why better recovery, inheritance, and UX matter more than ever. We talk Lightning as the default payment rail, custodial tradeoffs for small amounts, and what sovereignty really means in practice.

The conversation drifts into AI, productivity, and why this shift feels bigger than anything we expected a few years ago. We also touch on privacy, regulation, and why that side of Bitcoin feels stalled despite better tools. This is a thoughtful conversation on building, patience, and why understanding Bitcoin matters more than chasing green candles.

item.title: Bitcoin, Fiat & Rock'n'Roll â€“ EU Goes All-In, Stablecoins Scale, Equities Tokenize | News
item.description:
Close out 2025 with BFRRâ€™s final news episode of the yearâ€”a fast-paced, institution-focused tour through what might be the most consequential month yet for blockchain in finance. Host Michael Blaschke is joined by Ivica AraÄiÄ‡ and Atakan Kavukluto to unpack Decemberâ€™s biggest developments across markets, regulation, stablecoins, and tokenizationâ€”and to zoom out on what 2025 really meant for institutional adoption.

We start with a market pulse (recorded on December 22): crypto closes the year strong, with the total market rebounding to roughly $3.8T, Bitcoin hovering around $90k, and stablecoins hitting new scaleâ€”with Tether and Circle together surpassing $260B. But the real story isnâ€™t price. Itâ€™s infrastructure.

Ivica breaks down major European policy momentum, including updates to the EUâ€™s DLT Pilot Regime aimed at expanding eligible instruments, raising caps, reducing friction for smaller participants, and strengthening long-term certainty. The episode also tackles the digital euroâ€™s political reality: the ECB pushes for legislative progress, while coordination challenges across parliaments, banks, and incentives remain the hard part.

Michael then dives into the â€œstablecoin yearâ€ thesis: regulated clarity meets real-world rollout. From SoFi USD as a bank-issued stablecoin in the US, to a major European bank consortium targeting a EUR stablecoin, to payment giants integrating stablecoins at scaleâ€”PayPalâ€™s PYUSD moving into AI infrastructure financing, YouTube enabling creator payouts in PYUSD, Intuit embedding USDC across finance workflows, and Visa expanding USDC settlement (including on Solana).

Atakan rounds out the month with tokenization and TradFi integration: landmark pilots like JP Morgan arranging commercial paper on Solana, tokenized money market funds (JP Morgan and Amundi on Ethereum), and the early hints of tokenized equities distribution via crypto platforms and messaging-first experiences.

The episode ends with a sharp 2025 wrap: stablecoins as the bridge between old rails and new networks, regulatory maturation finally arriving, and a growing tilt toward public blockchain infrastructureâ€”plus reading recommendations (BIS Project Rialto, an IMF stablecoin primer, and Christian Catalini on the â€œtrillion-dollar battleâ€ for moneyâ€™s operating system).

item.title: Bitcoiners - Live From Bitcoin Beach â€“ Knut Svanholm: Why Iâ€™m Considering Moving to El Salvador After Meeting Bukele (And You Should Too!)
item.description:
What if democracy canâ€™t survive sound money, because it runs on promises it canâ€™t fund?

Knut Svanholm sits down with Mike Peterson in El Salvador, fresh from a formal night at the presidential palace with President Nayib Bukele. Phones taken, press everywhere, and a president who feels unnervingly normal to Bitcoiners. Knutâ€™s take is blunt, El Salvador may have accidentally voted â€œone of usâ€ into office, and the results feel like the inverse of clown world.

Then the conversation turns to the cage, fiat currency. They break down how money printing, capital gains tax, and government overreach work together to punish anyone trying to use sound money as an inflation hedge. If you have ever felt like you are being taxed for refusing to play the inflation game, this will hit a nerve.

From Centro HistÃ³rico to El Zonte, they get practical about what Bitcoin adoption actually looks like when it is not just â€œnumber go upâ€ technology. A circular economy takes time, merchant by merchant orange pill work, and more people using the Lightning Network for everyday payments instead of treating Bitcoin like a museum piece.

They widen out to Madeira and Prague, where Bitcoin communities are forming in their own ways. You will hear why BTCmap.org (https://btcmap.org/) matters, why Prague gets called the Bitcoin capital of Europe, and why Vexl is one of the most interesting peer-to-peer tools right now for building a web of trust when rules tighten.

Finally, Knut leans into his anarcho-capitalism lens, the Shawshank Redemption metaphor, and the mindset behind â€œyou can just do things.â€ If this episode made you uncomfortable, good, subscribe, share it with the friend still asking permission.

item.title: Epicenter - Learn about Crypto, Blockchain, Ethereum, Bitcoin and Distributed Technologies â€“ Solving The AI Black Box: ZK-Proofs in Defence Tech
item.description:
In this episode, host Sebastian Couture is joined by Ismael Hishon-Rezaizadeh, CEO of Lagrange, to explore the intersection of frontier cryptography and national security. Ismael discusses the transition of zero-knowledge (ZK) technology from a "token-centric" crypto tool to a vital component of defense, specifically focusing on its role in securing autonomous drone swarms and closing the hypersonic missile gap.




They delve into Deep Proof, Lagrange's ZK-machine learning library, which facilitates verifiable AI execution while protecting sensitive model intellectual property and private input data. Ismael introduces the concept of "Accountable Autonomy," arguing that cryptographic proofs are necessary to ensure that lethal "kill chain" decisions are made by the correct models under verified inputs, removing the risks inherent in "black box" AI decision-making. Finally, the conversation touches on the geopolitical competition with China, the importance of domestic chip manufacturing, and why the US market's ability to align private sector innovation with military needs is a decisive strategic advantage.


Topics

  • 00:00 Intro & Context
  • 04:15 ZKML vs. Venice
  • 09:30 Protecting Model IP
  • 15:00 Dual-Use Defense Pivot
  • 21:45 The Palantir Comparison
  • 27:10 US-China Chip Race
  • 35:20 Drone Swarm Consensus
  • 42:15 Accountable Autonomy Explained
  • 49:00 Kill Chain Verifiability
  • 55:30 EU vs. US Defense

item.title: Thank God for Bitcoin â€“ TGFB Episode 73: If You're Going To Win, You're Going To Have To Plod: A Convo With Nate Spearing
item.description:
Nathan Spearing shares his journey from a military career to entrepreneurship, emphasizing the importance of time, family, and courage in making life decisions. He discusses the challenges of transitioning from a structured military environment to the uncertainties of business, and the significance of building a legacy for future generations.

Nathan Spearing and Jordan Bush explore various themes related to education, biblical principles of sowing and reaping, the importance of community, and the role of prayer in daily life. The conversation also touches on practical wisdom for preparing for the future, the significance of Bitcoin as a new perspective on wealth before closing with a few practial Bitcoin questions.

item.title: VERIFIED by Bitcoin Suisse â€“ Crypto Outlook 2026
item.description:
In this episode of the Verified Podcast by Bitcoin Suisse, Dominic Weibel sits down with investment strategist DenisÂ Oevermann, crypto market analyst LucaÂ Gnos, and junior portfolio manager Mateo Sansonetti to dissect crypto's performance in 2025 and share their predictions for 2026.Â 
Â 
The discussion examines why 2025 was a year where crypto overdelivered on fundamentals but underdelivered on price. The panel explores new regulatory frameworks, the pro-crypto stance of the U.S. administration, and the disjointed performance between Bitcoin and altcoins. They analyze the explosive growth of options trading, the rise of prediction markets, and how macroeconomic factors and institutional flows will shape 2026.Â 
Â 
The conversation also tackles AI's market influence, the potential for Federal Reserve rate cuts, retail sentiment versus institutional positioning, and price predictions for Bitcoin and Ethereum heading into the new year.

]]>
